The decision to continue or reform the filibuster rule is a matter of ongoing debate in the United States. Supporters of the filibuster argue that it is an important tool for maintaining the Senate's tradition of protecting minority rights and encouraging greater compromise and debate. Some also argue that eliminating the filibuster would lead to greater partisanship and less bipartisanship.

Opponents of the filibuster argue that it is an outdated rule that has been abused in recent years, leading to political gridlock and a lack of legislative progress on important issues. Some argue that the rule disproportionately benefits small states and minority parties and is a barrier to true majority rule.

Ultimately, the decision to continue or reform the filibuster rule is up to the members of the Senate. Some lawmakers have called for changes to the rule, such as requiring a talking filibuster, lowering the threshold for invoking cloture, or exempting certain types of legislative actions from the filibuster. Others have called for the filibuster to be eliminated altogether.
